title-group.article-title: Dibenzo-tetraphenyl diindeno perylene as hole transport layer for high-bandgap perovskite solar cells

institution-wrap.institution: BCMaterials, Basque Center for Materials, Applications and Nanostructures

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Semi-transparent perovskite solar cells have the competitive edge of being employed for building integrated photovoltaics due to their esthetic benefits as light harvesting windows/facades. Perovskites have received considerable attention in recent years as a thin film photovoltaic alternative, that can also be tweaked for its transparency, evolving from potentially high bandgaps that are suited for semi-transparent solar cell fabrication. Due to the existing trade of between the efficiency and transparency of a perovskite solar cell, tuning the band gap can address this by making a bridge between the aforementioned parameters. We report our findings on the use of a wide-bandgap perovskite MAPbBr3, with a rational energetic level hole transport materials based on polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon molecules that can be a promising alternative class of p-type material. In the present work, DBP (Dibenzo{[f,f′]-4,4′,7,7′-tetraphenyl}diindeno[1,2,3-cd :1′,2′,3′-lm]perylene was evaluated with high bandgap as well as with mixed (FAPbI3)0.85(MAPbBr3)0.15 perovskites for the fabrication of solar cell. DBP-based solar cells yielded competitive power conversion efficiencies as compared with classical HTMs.

custom-meta.meta-value: Qatar University and Springer Nature Switzerland AG

notes.title: Electronic supplementary material
notes.p: The online version of this article (https://doi.org/10.1007/s42247-020-00098-x) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently developed metal halide perovskites [1, 2] have generated a significant interest in the photovoltaic (PV) field, and the current decade has witnessed notable progress in its investigation. Such perovskites can be expressed as ABX3, where A stands for organic or inorganic metal cation, B is a metal ion, and X is an anion which is generally halide [3–5]. The bromide-based hybrid perovskites, in particular, are intriguing due to their large bandgap of 2.2–2.4 eV that also allows them to serve as a top layer for dual-junction tandem solar cells with crystalline Si or copper indium gallium diselenide (CIGS) [6–8]. Bromide-based perovskites exhibit high absorption coefficient and furthermore are relatively stable against humidity and moisture to yield higher device lifetimes [9–11]. Reducing the active layer thickness only is not a viable route for obtaining semi-transparent solar cells, as it may come along with significant drops in device performance [12]. The possibility of tweaking the absorption range by means of employing high-bandgap materials to regulate the absorption can be an ideal approach, which may also be highly suitable for tandem based devices.

Methylammonium lead bromide (MAPbBr3) was first implemented as sensitizers for titania scaffold in a liquid junction solar cells [13, 14]. The substitution of the bromine in the perovskite decreases the ionic size and thus alter the optical band gap, i.e., Eg of MAPbBr3 2.24 eV for single crystal and 2.32 eV for the polycrystalline films, yielding higher voltage potential in the devices. Using the crystallization-controlled spin coating process, the maximum efficiency of 10.4% has been achieved via the solution deposition method [15]. Mesoporous TiO2-based devices using MAPbBr3 via one-step solution deposition process as light harvester was fabricated with an open circuit voltage of up to 1.3 V. MAPbBr3 shows strong absorption at around 375 nm, and the photoluminescence emission of the film with an intense and narrow peak can be observed at around slightly red-shifted position at 543 nm [16]. By optimizing deposition conditions [17], solar cells based on formamidinium bromide–based were reported [18, 19]. A maximum power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 10.61% was reported by Zhang et al., followed by 8.2% PCE by Arora et al. FAPbBr3 has a narrow band gap of 2.23 eV as compared with MA-based perovskites (2.32 eV) for the polycrystalline films [20, 21]. The UV-vis absorbance peak for FAPbBr3 appears at 532 nm, whereas the photoluminescence peak was observed at 550 nm. Improved thermal stability of FAPbBr3 was reported by annealing the films at 150°C for 60 min [18, 19].

The classical hole transport material (HTM) such as Spiro-OMeTAD is not suitable in combination with high-bandgap perovskites, mainly due to its energetic level mismatch. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a class of organic molecules that have received significant attention due to their semiconducting applications in organic electronics and structural interests of well-defined graphene segments. Mullen et al. reported synthetic methodologies towards the development of pi-extended PAHs that allow achieving high efficiency and functionality [22, 23]. Similarly, graphene has been studied extensively as a potential material for organic electronics and semiconductors [24]. Efforts are being made to develop a class of PAHs that boost the semiconducting properties by developing pi-conjugated sp2 hydrocarbon–based molecules by functionalization with ketones, halogens, alkoxy, or amines to tune the optoelectronic response. Due to all-sp2 carbons and rigid π-extended planar backbone, PAH shows higher absorption in the visible region and good thermal and chemical stability that allows it to be exploited as semiconducting materials. It also has a narrow highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)–lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) band alignment that can improve charge transport. DBP (Dibenzo{[f,f′]-4,4′,7,7′-tetraphenyl}diindeno[1,2,3-cd:1′,2′,3′-lm]perylene) is a known polyaromatic hydrocarbon-based compound that has favorable known electrochemical and photo-physical properties [25]. It has been reported as dopants for emitter in OLEDs, applications in electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL), and as a donor material in both bulk and bilayer heterojunction organic solar cell fabrication [26–31]. We have also reported DBP as an electron donor with C70 as a bilayer in a planar heterojunction organic solar cell with a performance of 5.66% [32]. Here, we report our preliminary results on the fabrication of MAPbBr3, FAPbBr3, and (FAPbI3)0.85(MAPbBr3)0.15-based perovskite solar cells (PSCs) employing DBP as a hole transporting layer deposited in solution.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The chemicals were bought from Sigma-Aldrich, whereas 2,2′,7,7′-tetrakis(N,N-di-p-methoxyphenylamine)-9,9,-spirobifluorene (Spiro-OMeTAD) was acquired from Merck., Methylammonium iodide (MAI), formamidinium iodide (FAI), methylammonium bromide (MABr) were purchased from Dyesol. PbI2 and PbBr2 were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry (TCI); all the chemicals were employed without any treatment or purification. DBP was procured from LumTec (Luminescence Technology Corp., Taiwan).

sec.title: Device fabrication
sec.p: The fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO)-coated glasses (TEC15) were used as electrode and were cleaned prior to use, firstly by ultrasonication (2% Hellmanex water solution for 30 min) followed by rinsing with deionized water; acetone and isopropanol were sequentially and finally heated up to 500 °C for the removal of any organic residue. TiO2 compact layer was deposited on cleaned FTO substrate via spray pyrolysis at 450 °C using a precursor solution of titanium diisopropoxide bis(acetylacetonate) in anhydrous ethanol. After the spraying, the substrates were left at 450 °C for 30 min and left to cool down to acquire room temperature. Followed by this, a 100–150-nm of mesoporous TiO2 layer was deposited by spin coating process; for this, a (1:8) TiO2 paste (Dyesol 30 NR-D) diluted in ethanol for 20 s at 4000 rpm was used. The substrates were dried at 125 °C and then annealed at 250 °C for 10 min, 350 °C for 10 min, 450 °C for 10 min in a four-step temperature ramp, and finally maintained at 500 °C for 30 min to allow transformation of amorphous TiO2 into anatase. When room temperature is attained, the substrates were transferred to an argon-filled glove box for perovskite layer deposition. The precursor solution for preparing the mixed perovskite was prepared by dissolving FAI (1 M), PbI2 (1.2 M), MABr (0.2 M), and PbBr2 (0.2 M) in anhydrous DMF:DMSO 4:1 (v:v). The perovskite solution was spin-coated in a two-step sequence at 1000 and 6000 rpm for 10 and 20 s, respectively. During the second step, 100 μL of chlorobenzene was dripped as an antisolvent approach on the substrate 10 s prior the end of the spinning process. The perovskite-coated substrates were annealed at 100 °C for 1 h in a glove box. On acquiring room temperature, the hole transport layer was deposited. Spiro-OMeTAD (70 mM) or DBP (in three different concentrations: 10, 20, and 30 mM) was prepared by dissolving the corresponding amount of materials in chlorobenzene. Spiro-OMeTAD was doped by adding bis-(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide lithium salt (Li-TFSI), tris(2-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-4-tert-butylpyridine) cobalt(III)-tris(bis-(trifluoro-methan)sulfonylimide) (FK209), and 4-tert-Butylpyridine (t-BP) in the molar ratio 0.5, 0.01, and 3.3 respectively. DBP were doped by adding LiTFSI and t-BP as an additive in the molar ratio of 0.5 and 3.3 respectively. A total of 35 μL of HTM solutions was spin-coated atop of the perovskite layer at 4000 rpm for 20 s, in a dry air filled glove box. To finish the device fabrication, gold layer of 70–80 nm as cathode was thermally evaporated under low vacuum (10−6 Torr). All solutions were prepared inside an argon-filled glove box with controlled moisture and oxygen conditions (O2 < 10 ppm, H2O < 2 ppm).

sec.title: Device characterization
sec.p: The fabricated solar cell figure of merit was measured using current density–voltage (J-V) curves, recorded with a Keithley 2400 source-measurement-unit under AM 1.5 G, 100 mW cm2 illumination from a 450 W AAA solar simulator (ORIEL, 94023 A). NREL-certified monocrystalline silicon solar cell was used for calibration. A black metal mask (0.16 cm2) was used over the square size active area (0.5 cm2) to reduce the influence of scattered light. Photovoltaic parameters including JSC, VOC, fill factor (FF), and power conversion efficiency (PCE) were extracted from the photocurrent–voltage (J-V) curves of the solar cells (scan rate, 100 mV s−1; pre-sweep delay, 10 s). The incident photon to-current efficiencyr (IPCE) measurements were performed using a Newport 150 W xenon lamp coupled to an Oriel Cornerstone 260 motorized 1/4 m monochromator as the light source, and a 2936-R power meter to measure the short circuit current.

sec.title: Result and discussions
sec.p:
The fabricated perovskite solar cells are depicted in Fig. S1, and bromide-based high-bandgap perovskites represent the semi-transparent nature. Figure 1a represents the band alignment and the relative energy levels of all the materials used in the present work. The calculated conductivity of undoped DBP was found to be 1.2 × 10−6 S/cm (Fig. S2). The DBP (structure depicted in Fig.1b)-based hole transport layers (HTLs) possess a HOMO level of − 5.5 and has favorable energy level match with MAPbBr3 or FAPbBr3, with HOMO levels of − 5.68 eV and − 5.6 eV. The PSCs were fabricated using DBP as HTL, in a conventional mesoporous architecture such as FTO/c-TiO2/meso-TiO2/perovskites/HTM/Au. The thickness of the DBP layer was optimized using three different concentrations, 10 mM, 20 mM, and 30 mM, respectively. To elucidate the device architecture used as well as the morphology and microstructure of the perovskite film, scanning electron microscopy experiments were conducted. The cross-sectional image of a working device is represented in Fig. 1c and demonstrates interconnected and well-defined layers. In this case, the perovskite active layer is the thickest layer, while the HTM layer is buried (due to very low thickness) between the perovskite and gold layer. A thin and compact mesoporous TiO2 layer is revealed in the SEM image. In a typical fabricated solar cells, the thickness measured from the cross-sectional SEM image, the layers were calculated as c-TiO2 ~ 50 nm, meso-TiO2 151 nm, MAPbBr3 312 nm, DBP 63 nm, and Au 71 nm respectively. DBP possesses several distinctive features that have been utilized as electron-donor materials in organic solar cells [33]. DBP has a deep lying HOMO level of − 5.5 eV and a LUMO level of − 3.5 eV, matching well to several electron acceptor materials, and it has a strong absorption wavelength in the visible region from 300 to 700 nm [34]. Recently, it was also introduced to the perovskite device fabrication [35], where the hole transport properties of the molecule can also make it well-suited as an interlayer.Fig. 1
(a) Energy level diagram of the fabricated perovskite solar cells, (b) molecular structure of DBP, and (c) cross-sectional diagram for the fabricated DBP-based perovskite solar cells.

The UV-vis absorbance spectra of the DBP in chlorobenzene (Fig. 2) show the Soret bands around 500–600 nm. Figure 2a shows the UV-visible absorption spectra of DBP films of different thickness, while Fig. 2b–d shows UV-visible absorption spectra of DBP with the perovskite active layer. DBP exhibits multiple absorption peaks in the visible region at 521, 556, and 609 nm which is due to the π-π* transition in the conjugated system. A side shoulder peak appears at 480 nm representing minute absorption in the UV-region. The λmax is at around 610 nm. We note that the thickness investigated here has a smaller effect on the absorbance peak, while thinner films represent comparatively lower intensity.Fig. 2
UV-vis absorbance spectra for spin coated (a) DBP layer at different speed (i.e., thickness), (b) FAPbBr3 + HTM, (c) MAPbBr3 + HTM, and (d) (FAPbI3)0.85(MAPbBr3)0.15 + HTM.

For the figure of merit calculation of the fabricated PV devices, the J-V curves were recorded under 1 sun-simulated air mass 1.5 global (AM1.5G) sunlight. Figure 3 illustrates the J-V characteristics under illumination at 100 mW/cm2 for the devices in reverse direction (from Voc to Jsc) at 100 mV/s. Table 1 summarizes the average PV parameters with the value of series resistance and shunt resistance.Fig. 3
(a) J-V curve for the DBP-based perovskite solar cells with FAPbBr3 and MAPbBr3, (b) incident photon-to-current efficiency of the DBP-based perovskite solar cells with FAPbBr3 and MAPbBr3, (c) J-V curve for the DBP with mixed perovskites, i.e., (FAPbI3)0.85(MAPbBr3)0.15, and (d) incident photon-to-current efficiency of the DBP with mixed perovskiteTable 1

The increase in short circuit current density (Jsc) with the usage of mixed perovskites was expected due to shifting of absorption onset to longer wavelength. The average Jsc and fill factor (FF) increased gradually from to 18.71 mAcm−2 and 55.17%. The lowest value for Jsc was observed for MAPbBr3, which is in line with the optical absorption of these two perovskite active layers (Fig. 2). A drop in Voc was noted with respect to MAPbBr3 (Voc = 1152 mV) for the mixed perovskites (Voc = 880 mV) due to a reduced band gap, which is in accordance with previous results. A relatively lower FF was observed in case of mixed perovskites, due to unbalanced charge extraction causing increased series resistance in the PV performance. It can be deduced from the Fig. 3 that there is an improvement in the average PCE in the case of mixed perovskite as compared with that of pure bromide-based perovksites, due to panchromatic light harvesting. We noted that thinner layers of DBP (10 mM) worked effectively for the bromide-based high-bandgap perovskite cells as compared with that of Spiro-OMeTAD (Fig. S3). By reducing the concentrations of DBP, thinner HTLs can be formed, which shows improved device performance (Fig. 4). We speculate that this is due to a decrease in series resistance and from that more effective charge extraction. In general, the open circuit voltages for the MAPbBr3 cells were high > 1150 mV, due to the use of high-bandgap perovskites. The performance limiting parameter was the short circuit current, which was low due to the use of MAPbBr3 as active layer (limited absorption, Fig. 2), while the FF close to 0.6 was obtained. Our calculated hysteresis index value for MAPbBr3-based devices was 0.047, while for FAPbBr3-based devices, we noted a value of 0.084 by using DBP has HTM.Fig. 4
(a) Effect of DBP thickness, J-V curve for the mixed perovskite solar cells with different thickness of DBP and (b) for comparative purpose, FAPbBr3-based perovskite solar cells with 10 mM DBP and standard (70 mM) Spiro-OMeTAD.

In the case of mixed perovskites, higher current values were noted with an PCE value > 9.1%. The incident photon-to-current efficiency (IPCE) measurement region was recorded in the wavelength range of 300–850 nm, where the active layer shows photoconversion. In agreement with the absorbance experiments, the formamidinium cation–based solar cells resulted in shifting of IPCE onset towards red part of the spectrum. For FAPbBr3, approx. 60% light to electricity conversion can be observed in the visible part of the spectra. This indicates that excitons and/or free charges were effectively generated in the perovskite layers upon light illumination.

Though promising photovoltaic performances were obtained, from optimizing the thickness of HTL, the reported PCE is relatively lower. In particular, the relatively low FF of the DBP-based devices could be due to the relatively lower hole transport ability of these materials, supported by the presence of high series resistance. Thus, by reducing the concentration of the DBP precursor solutions and correspondingly the HTL thickness, we could partially mitigate that problem. The reduced charge carrier mobility is partly due to the molecular packing in the film formation, originating due to the steric hindrance of the bulky substituents on the polyaromatic moiety. The open circuit voltage relatively remains constant, on reducing the thickness of HTL, as the mismatch in the energetic levels of these new molecules with the perovskites are relatively low.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: To summarize, we presented the usage of DBP (Dibenzo{[f,f′]-4,4′,7,7′-tetraphenyl}diindeno[1,2,3-cd :1′,2′,3′-lm]perylene, highly soluble in common organic solvents. DBP was used as a hole transport layer utilizing solution process route, for the perovskite solar cell fabrication and efficiency in excess of 9% was achieved. The thickness of DBP as a hole selective layer was optimized by concentration tweaking; we noted the device performance can be enhanced by using thin DBP layers. The optimized thickness of DBP-based hole transport layer gave competitive power conversion efficiencies, signaling potential use of DBP as a hole transport layer for high-bandgap perovskites. Semi-transparent solar cells that require the usage of transparent and effective light harvesters have the added advantage of being used in BIPV due to its esthetic benefits were also fabricated utilizing high-bandgap perovskites. The presented results will imply the research direction for fabricating efficient semi-transparent solar cells.

sec.title: Funding information
sec.p: This work has received funding from the European Union H2020 Programme under European Research Council Consolidator grant (MOLEMAT, 726360) and ITN-Thinface (FP7).

sec.title: Conflict of interests
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
